field_edited_text.value:
40

requested its inclusion in the plan, the City
reconsidered and decided to do so.

2. At the behest of the Department of Transit
and Traffic, the Planning Department favorably
recommended a proposal to widen Pennsylvania
Avenue and convert it into a six-lane
thoroughfare. Over the objections of the Small
Business Committee, the plan cleared the
various agencies and was submitted to the
Mayor for final approval. Again, it was through
the efforts of the Upton Planning Committee
that the Mayor decided against it.

3. Consultants for a metropolitan mass transit
system had recommended an express stop some
distance removed from the core of the
Pennsylvania Avenue business area. After
meeting with the Upton Planning Committee,
the plan was revised and the recommended stop
placed in the heart of the business area.

Because the preponderance of the viable
businesses in the core area were white-owned
and almost 100% of the shoppers were Black,
one of the objectives of the Demonstration
Project was to create an integrated business
community through encouraging and abetting

minority entrepreneurship. At the beginning of
the project, while a number of the stores had
Black managers, there was only one Black
owner in the P.A.L.M.A. business association.
Today, there are five, and one of the largest
stores in the area is on the verge of making the
transition from white to Black ownership.
There is a strong possibility that within the
next decade, the majority of the businesses in
this area will be owned by Black entrepreneurs.

Participation in deliberations of the Upton
Planning Committee was not without problems
for the white businessmen. In many cases, their
motives were viewed with suspicion and they
were constantly put on the defensive. Several of
the white businessmen failed to understand the
psychological necessity that impelled the
distrust and antagonism, and gave up after one
or two meetings. However, those that remained
witnessed a marked decrease in hostility and a
concomitant increase in communication.
Transcending all personal hang-ups, there
emerged the intense desire of the residents for a
better community for their children than the
one in which they were raised. After two years
of meetings, agreements and disagreements,
frustrations and aggravation, pleasant

discussions and harsh words, a final approval
was given to the Upton Urban Renewal Plan
and signed by the Mayor. It is significant that
the final approved plan on which
implementation will begin within the year bears
a remarkable similarity to the concept
developed earlier on the Demonstration Project
as contained in this report. There were those
who felt that the same results could have been
achieved in less time and with far less effort,
and while they may be right, it is equally true
that the plan will be more meaningful to those
affected by it because they had a voice in its
preparation.
